2 The Hierarchical Model

The overall objective for our hierarchical model is to identify anomalous prices every day but only alert farmers when we have confident results to show them. To achieve this objective, we use SARIMAX as time model to do a first step filter followed by 2 different space models, Generalized Linear Model and a simple baseline model to cross compare detected anomalies.

2.1 The SARIMAX Model

We employ a SARIMAX model for each individual elevator to forecast the current price of the commodity based on past historical data. SARIMAX stands for Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average with exogenous variables.

Given a time series of corn basis prices yt for t=0,1,…,T−1, the generalized form of a SARIMAX(p, r, q)(a, b, c, d) model with a constant trend. The model is defined as follows:

Δr⁢yt=c+∑i=1pϕi⁢Δr⁢yt−i+∑j=1qθj⁢ϵt−j+∑k=1aΦk⁢Δb⁢yt−k⁢d+∑l=1cΘl⁢Δb⁢ϵt−l⁢d+ϵt, (1)

where:

  • •

    yt represents the corn basis price at time t,

  • •

    Δr⁢yt is the r-times differenced time series,

  • •

    c is the constant trend,

  • •

    ϕi are the autoregressive coefficients for i=1,2,3,…,p,

  • •

    θj are the moving average coefficients for j=1,2,3,…,q,

  • •

    Φk are the seasonal autoregressive coefficients for k=1,2,3,…,a,

  • •

    Θl are the seasonal moving average coefficients for l=1,2,3,…,c,

  • •

    Δb⁢yt−k⁢d and Δb⁢ϵt−l⁢d are the seasonally differenced time series and error terms, respectively,

  • •

    d is the number of time steps per season (seasonal period),

  • •

    ϵt is the error term at time t.

The model is fitted using the corn basis price time series from yesterday (t−1) to the furthest day in the past (0). The predicted value is the corn basis price for today (t).
Please note that at the moment, we have not taken into account exogenous variables, integration (as stationarity assumption holds), and seasonality terms due to limited basis data of approximately 170 days. We did not identify any significant seasonality orders for our model. We constructed our model to incorporate the following:

  • •

    Autoregressive lags: (lags of past price terms), captures the long-term dependency or patterns in the price series, allowing the model to incorporate historical information and capture trends or momentum in the data.

  • •

    Moving average lags: (lags of past prediction error terms), captures short-term fluctuations or noise in the data by considering the deviations between the actual and predicted values in previous time steps. By incorporating these error terms, the model can adjust its predictions based on the past forecasting inaccuracies, improving its ability to account for short-term volatility or random fluctuations.

For simplicity we set one unifying MA lag and AR lag across all of the times series, we utilize the mean moving average and autoregressive lag across all of the time series. To determine the appropriate lags for the autoregressive and moving average terms, we examine the ACF (AutoCorrelation Function) and PACF (Partial AutoCorrelation Function) plots.

The ACF plot describes the mean autocorrelation across all time series. The correlations are represented by the bars, and the light shaded area at the back is the 95 percents confidence intervals. The optimal value of autoregressive lag corresponds to the number of bars that exceeds the confidence interval, indicating that the correlation is likely to be due to a real underlying relationship rather than random noise. In this case, the optimal number of AR lag that we choose is 12.

To find the optimal moving average term, we look at the PACF. The partial autocorrelation plot describes the relationship between the current and lagged observation after removing the effects of all other lags in between. Comparing and contrasting the two, we learn that the shock is communicated mainly through the autoregressive terms. The PACF plot suggests we should choose a moving average order of 1.

As a result our current SARIMAX model is essentially an ARMA model whose underlying mathematical model is given as such:

yt=c+∑i=112ϕi⁢yt−i+θ1⁢ϵt−1+ϵt, (2)

where:

  • •

    yt represents the corn basis price at time t,

  • •

    c is the constant trend,

  • •

    ϕi are the autoregressive coefficients for i=1,2,3,…,12,

  • •

    θj are the moving average coefficients for j=1,

  • •

    ϵt is the error term at time t.

Potential Future Work

While the analysis before pertains to only the average time series, in production, we would conduct hyperparameter search to determine the optimal hyperparameters to use and additionally, incorporate more terms into the time series model.

On a quarterly basis, we update the best hyperparameters to azure. On a daily basis, we retrieve them for prediction for inference and to fit our model. The best hyperparameters would vary across different time series as they individually exhibit different trends. Some are more sensitive to exogenous shocks than others.

2.2 Baseline Model

On a 2-dimensional surface, we aim to identify elevators that exhibit significantly different behavior compared to their neighboring elevators.

The baseline model takes a fixed number of 10 neighboring elevators’ Z score for each detected anomalous elevator from the time series, and compare that anomalous Z-score against the mean of its 10 neighbors. The formula is given as such: z=y−μσ where μ=1n⁢∑i=1nyi and σ=1n⁢∑i=1n(yi−μ)2

By comparing the Z-score of an anomalous elevator against the mean Z-scores of its neighboring elevators, the model assesses the relative deviation of the elevator’s behavior within its local context. If the Z-score of the anomalous elevator is significantly higher or lower than the mean Z-scores of its neighbors, it suggests that the elevator’s behavior stands out and deviates from the expected pattern.

2.3 The Kernel Regression

The baseline model is too coarse it only considers a fixed number of neighboring elevators. This approach assumes that the immediate neighbors provide equal context for determining whether an elevator is anomalous or not. Yet, the assumptions made are unrealistic as some elevators may exhibit a higher degree of sensitivity to surrounding elevator prices, vice versa. In this section, we instead utilize a kernel to model the price diffusion across a 2D plane by taking inter-elevator distance as an input to the regression problem.

Instead of using prices directly as inputs in this model, we opt to use the differences between consecutive prices. This approach tackles the problem of autocorrelation, as price differences are not correlated with each other and adhere to the Gauss-Markov assumption of a linear model.

Δ⁢P=Pnew−Pold

On a given date, given y is the price difference of elevator we want to predict and x1,…⁢xn are prices differences of the n closest elevators , we want to formulate a kernel function such that:

y^=∑i=1NK⁢(xi)⋅xi∑j=1NK⁢(xi)
K⁢(xj)=e−β⁢dxj,y2

where dxj,y is the distance between the locations of elevators xj and y.

The β, and the number of elevators n, are both hyper-parameters to the model.

2.4 Model testing and results - SARIMAX + Kernel Regression

We utilized data from 10-Oct-2022 to 1-Apr-2023 as the training set and applied a 80 - 20 split to divide this into the train and validation set. For each elevator, we find the best hyperparameter (the number of neighbouring elevators) that minimizes the MAE on the validation set.

We tested the model on data as of 3-May-2023.

We find there is a relatively small number of elevators with high mean absolute errors. These elevators are potential candidates for the anomalies we want to flag.

Macro picture of model results

Visualizing our results over the US map, we observe that elevators characterized by low error rates (indicated by darker blue dots) consistently exhibit a limited number of neighbors identified as the optimal hyper-parameter (depicted as darker red). While this observation does not establish a causal relationship, it suggests a compelling interpretation: certain elevators display a high degree of correlation with their neighboring prices, resulting in improved predictability when considering only a small subset of neighbors. Consequently, we can infer that utilizing the closest neighbors as predictors of price yields favorable results and can be considered a reliable predictor in these instances. This finding supports the notion that localized factors, captured by a small number of nearby elevators, significantly contribute to the price dynamics of individual elevators.

2.5 Enhanced Anomaly Detection: two layered filtering

The ultimate output of both the SARIMAX model and the Kernel regression is one z-score estimate for every elevator. For every elevator, we compute:

z=p⁢r⁢e⁢d⁢i⁢c⁢t⁢e⁢d⁢p⁢r⁢i⁢c⁢e−e⁢x⁢p⁢e⁢c⁢t⁢e⁢d⁢p⁢r⁢i⁢c⁢eσp⁢r⁢i⁢c⁢e

We use the SARIMAX model and the spatial models as a two layered filter to find anomalous elevators with a significant z-score from both the space and time dimensions. We carefully design the thresholds beyond which the elevators would be classified as truly anomalous.

2.6 An example of an anomalous elevator

Using our model, an anomalous elevator that we have detected is depicted below:

This particular elevator experiences a significant and consistent increase in price over time, in contrast to its neighboring elevators, which either maintain a flat price or exhibit a decreasing trend. Despite the absence of a general upward movement in prices among its neighbors, this elevator stands out with its persistently rising price trajectory.
